Award.AwardTitle: Faculty of Color Uncovering Success Strategies in Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Across the nation, there is a critical need to increase the diversity of faculty in STEM fields, such as engineering. The 2014 NACME report indicated, in 2011,that racial/ethnic minorities comprised 4.8% of full professors, 7.6% of associate professors, and 8.2% of assistant professors in engineering. Moreover, the percentages for racial/ethnic groups, at each rank, are even lower. Of further concern is the fact, at the highest faculty ranks, that there are fewer numbers of racial/ethnic minority faculty represented, indicating that racial/ethnic minority faculty members are leaving their faculty positions before promotion and tenure to associate professor and/or staying at associate professor and not going up for promotion to full professor. It is well-documented in the theoretical and scientific literature that underrepresented, engineering faculty members experience many challenges in the professoriate, which oftentimes compromise their success. This proposed 12-week project addresses some of the many challenges that tenure-track, engineering faculty of color experience in the professoriate. During the 12-week program, underrepresented engineering faculty participants will learn specific skills and techniques, designed to help them identify, prioritize and plan their research and writing goals. Participants will also develop a strategic plan and have weekly planning meetings. Each week, the participants will learn a specific tool or strategy for faculty success, including building their mentor network, aligning their time with research and writing priorities, writing through resistance, and self care strategies. They will also work with a faculty success coach and meet once a week with this person throughout the 12-week program. It is also believed that the program has great probability to help advance the careers of participants of the program.

The results of the 12-week program also have the potential to change and shape how engineering faculty approach teaching, research, and service in ways that lead to long-term success and increased productivity and satisfaction among underrepresented engineering faculty. further, participating faculty members will obtain a set of tools to not only use for themselves but also to mentor and support other tenure-track, engineering faculty members. The methods to achieve faculty success entail the following:
1) During the summer 2017, five underrepresented faculty of color in the College of Engineering will be selected to participate in the faculty success program.
2) Participating faculty members will engage in a 12-week faculty success program during the fall semester, which teaches them how to plan and develop healthy relationships and achieve work-life integration.
3) There will be ongoing data collection on faculty productivity and faculty development outcomes to determine the program's impact on faculty productivity and work-life integration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A primary goal of the National Science Foundation Broadening Participation in Engineering (BPE) program is to increase diversity and retain underrepresented populations in Engineering. This project focused on providing professional development and support for early career faculty of color in Engineering. It is clear from the literature on faculty development that there are many structural issues embedded within the tenure-track system that make it challenging to thrive in the academy, particularly for underrepresented faculty.  

 

This project provided financial support for five early career engineering faculty of color to enroll in a 12-week Bootcamp. During the 12-week Bootcamp, participants learned planning and time management skills to maximize their productivity, expanded their mentor networks, and held themselves accountable for research and writing every week. In addition to the 12-week Bootcamp, participants enrolled in the 12-week alumni program the following semester and continued to practice the strategies and skills they learned in the Bootcamp. Participants completed the alumni program using a peer mentoring model that consisted of weekly accountability meetings with other alumni program faculty across the country.

 

Data were collected from participants throughout the project. Individual interviews were conducted with each participant before and after the Bootcamp and a focus group interview was conducted at the end of the alumni program. Several themes emerged from the data that reflect their experiences before, during, and after the Bootcamp experience:

 

  • The importance of race and gender for early-career faculty

  • Thriving versus Surviving

  • Creating spaces for mentoring and support

  • Self-care & academia: The importance of work-life integration

  • Working in silos versus in community

 

Participants reported that they learned the importance of planning, how to align their time with their priorities, how to cultivate a network of mentors and sponsors and the importance of working in community.
